title: Republicans Don’t Want to Talk About Jan. 6. Trump Can’t Help Himself.
abstract: Donald J. Trump has made his revisionist account of the Capitol attack the foundation of this campaign, even when there is little political advantage.
byline: By Charles Homans and Alan Feuer
org_facet: House Select Committee to Investigate the January 6th Attack

multimedia.caption: Former President Donald J. Trump has called the attack on the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, a “love fest” and the jailed rioters “hostages.”

title: In Politically Divided America, Even the Walz Family Has Painful Rifts
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz of Minnesota, the Democratic vice-presidential nominee, has lamented the angry splits within families over politics. But he and his Republican brother rarely speak.

multimedia.caption: The political differences between Tim Walz and his brother Jeff Walz reflect the divisions that have torn apart many families in this deeply divided moment in the nation’s history.
multimedia.copyright: Emily Elconin for The New York Times

title: Ukrainian Troops Talk of Stiffer Resistance as They Fight in Russian Territory
abstract: Soldiers and military analysts say that Ukraine is largely holding onto land it seized in the Kursk region, even as Moscow has begun a counterattack.
byline: By Marc Santora and David Guttenfelder

multimedia.caption: Digging through the wreckage of a home after a missile strike on a neighborhood in Sumy, Ukraine, on Sunday.
Digging through the wreckage of a home after a missile strike on a neighborhood in Sumy, Ukraine, on Sunday.

title: Meeting With Biden, British Leader Hints at Ukraine Weapon Decision Soon
abstract: As the president deliberated with Prime Minister Keir Starmer, the question of whether to let Ukraine use long-range weapons in Russia was a rare point of contention between allied nations.
byline: By Michael D. Shear and David E. Sanger

multimedia.caption: President Biden and Prime Minister Keir Starmer of Britain during a bilateral meeting at the White House on Friday.

title: The Long-Range Weapons Ukraine Wants to Use on Russia, Explained
abstract: The United States and its allies are once again considering expanding the capabilities they provide to Ukraine in its fight against Russia’s invasion.

title: A Year After a Deadly Flood, a Libyan City Is Rebuilding but Not Whole
abstract: Derna is quickly being reconstructed after a flood that killed thousands. But questions linger about the process, and residents say new buildings cannot erase their trauma.
byline: By Vivian Yee and Mauricio Lima

multimedia.caption: One of the new bridges under construction in Derna, Libya.

title: Should a ‘Diverse’ Campus Mean More Conservatives?
abstract: Republicans are demanding colleges embrace “viewpoint diversity.” They aren’t the only ones who are concerned.

title: Paraguay Loves Mickey, the Cartoon Mouse. Just Don’t Mention the D Word.
abstract: Mickey, a homegrown food-packaging company, is famous for facing down Disney in Paraguay’s Supreme Court. As the family business turns 90, why is it still so popular?
byline: By Laurence Blair and María Magdalena Arréllaga

title: At Funeral in Turkey, Family Mourns American Activist Killed by Israeli Gunfire
abstract: The father of Aysenur Ezgi Eygi, a dual citizen of Turkey and the United States, said that Washington had not done enough to pressure Israel over her death.
byline: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman

title: Sweeping Iraq Raid Killed 4 ISIS Leaders
abstract: The U.S. military said those killed in a joint assault by U.S. and Iraqi forces last month included the group’s top commander in Iraq and its leading bomb maker.

org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

title: After Commissioner’s Abrupt Exit, the N.Y.P.D. Struggles to Right Itself
abstract: The new top police officer will take over an agency that Mayor Eric Adams has seeded with loyalists, who have created an atmosphere of intrigue and aggression.
byline: By Maria Cramer and Hurubie Meko

title: Tracking Investigations In Eric Adams’s Orbit
abstract: Several federal corruption inquiries have reached into the world of Mayor Eric Adams of New York, who faces re-election next year. Here is a closer look at how people with ties to Adams are related to the inquiries.
byline: By Hurubie Meko and Elena Shao

title: Today’s Parents: ‘Exhausted, Burned Out and Perpetually Behind’
abstract: The surgeon general is warning about parents’ stress, a sign that intensive parenting may have become too intense for parents.

title: New Tariff Rules Could Reverse a ‘Paradigm Shift’ in Retail
abstract: Under pressure from Chinese competitors, Amazon, Walmart and other U.S. retailers have been exploring ways to avoid tariffs. Could a new Biden administration rule change that?

title: A Georgia Work Program Previews How Trump Could Reshape Medicaid
abstract: The nation’s only Medicaid work program is part of a broad Republican push to change how poor people qualify for health care. In a second Trump term, Medicaid could be a target for huge spending cuts.

title: Police Fatally Shoot Brooklyn Man Hiding in a Bathtub
abstract: The man, Vilmond Jean Baptiste, was in an apartment in Flatbush. The police said he was wanted on a warrant from 2022 and was a person of interest in three homicides this summer.

title: Sexual Abuse Allegations Shatter a Crusading Priest’s Legacy

title: Earlier Investigation of School Shooting Suspect Ended Too Soon, Experts Say
abstract: The teenager charged in the Sept. 4 shooting in Georgia was questioned by the police last year about online threats. The investigator said he couldn’t determine if the teen had been the one behind them.
byline: By Shaila Dewan, Sean Keenan and Alessandro Marazzi Sassoon
